children.name: Chapter 4: Soft Tissue Injuries of the Face, Head

fields:
{{c1::Violence and motor vehicle accidents::2}} are among
the most common causes of facial injury in individuals aged 15 to
50 years old.

{{c1::Trips and falls}} the most common cause of isolated soft tissue injuries such
as laceration and contusions mainly in children and the elderly.

Overall {{c1::motor vehicle collisions}} are the most prevalent cause of
soft tissue damage to the face.
In the U.S.

Injured and exposed structures should be identified,
evaluated, and documented, with particular attention to
cranial nerves {{c1::V, VII, and XII}}.

This is critical in the conscious
patient and must be done prior to the use of any local
or general anesthetic. A nerve stimulator may be helpful to
stimulate the appropriate muscle groups in the nonparalyzed
patient under general anesthetic. If a nerve has been
damaged, appropriate microsurgical techniques should be
used to attempt to restore continuity and ultimate function
of the nerve. Always inquire about functional deficits that
existed prior to the injury.

Parotid duct injuries should be suspected in any patient
with lacerations extending from the {{c1::pretragal region}} to the
{{c1::middle half of the upper lip}}.

In patients with a suspected
parotid duct injury, the duct should be cannulated intraorally
at the level of the second maxillary molar and visualized
through the wound. The authors’ preference for
cannulation is the use of a {{c1::J-wire}} followed by an {{c2::intracatheter}}
placed over the {{c1::J-wire}}.

If parotid duct injury is poorly visualized
in the wound, liquids such as {{c1::propofol or methylene
blue::2}} may be injected into the duct to assess the location of
the injury.

Exposed cartilage that cannot be covered initially should
be dressed with {{c1::mafenide acetate (Sulfamylon) 5% or silver
sulfadiazine cream::2}}.

Neurovascular structures
that cannot be covered should be dressed with nonadherent
dressings such as {{c1::Xeroform gauze or Adaptic gauze::2}} with
or without {{c2::bacitracin}} ointment.
Abrasions and superficial burns can be dressed with {{c1::Adaptic}} gauze and {{c1::bacitracin}}.
Deep wounds that cannot be closed can be dressed initially with {{c1::hydrogel}} bandages, {{c2::normal saline Kerlix}} dressings or {{c3::iodoform}} gauze until definitive closure can be obtained.
Eyelid avulsion wounds require immediate {{c1::ophthalmic antibiotic ointment}} and an {{c2::occlusive eye shield}} to prevent exposure keratopathy.

In patients with soft tissue injuries that need tracheostomy there is a high associated mortality ({{c1::11.5}}%) and a significantly longer hospital stay than in patients with craniofacial fractures.

Documentation of the timing and mechanism of injury as well as postinjury signs and symptoms such as {{c1::loss of consciousness, nausea, and vomiting::3 signs of concussion}} should be used to guide assessment and management.
Time from injury to repairs recently has been shown to be {{c1::not specificially::related/not related}} to incidence of infections.

Berk, Osbourne, and Taylor
found that wound age was of little concern in wounds
located on the scalp and face.8
Factors such as {{c1::diabetes, wound contamination, length greater than 5 cm and location::4}} are important risk factors for wound infection.
{{c1::Impact crush}} injuries, for example, are as much as 100 times more susceptible to infection than are wounds caused by shear force.

Such wounds require pressure irrigation (< 15 psi) and debridement
of all nonviable soft tissue to prevent postoperative
infection. Also, photographs prior to injury are useful in
identifying preexisting deformities and facial morphology.

{{c1::Paper tape}} alone may be used for closure of
wounds that are superficial to the subcutaneous level, especially
in pediatric patients.
Staple closure may be used in a variety of circumstances but is most commonly used in the cutaneous closure of {{c1::scalp}}.

In complex wounds, multilayered closure is required to
eliminate {{c1::dead space}} and provide {{c1::wound eversion}}. This can
be accomplished with either an {{c2::interrupted}} suture or {{c2::continuous}}
suture technique.

Ideal Suture Material Characteristics:
1. {{c1::Minimal tissue injury}}
2. {{c2::Minimal tissue reaction}}
3. {{c3::Ease of handling}}
4. {{c4::High tensile strength}}
5. {{c5::Favorable absorption profile}}
6. {{c6::Resistance to infection}}
a5a3656c3ea24b3fbdfd1337d648ba16-oa-1
a5a3656c3ea24b3fbdfd1337d648ba16-oa-2
a5a3656c3ea24b3fbdfd1337d648ba16-oa-3
a5a3656c3ea24b3fbdfd1337d648ba16-oa-4
a5a3656c3ea24b3fbdfd1337d648ba16-oa-5
Absorbable synthetic fibers are polymers that degrade by hydrolysis and therefore cause {{c1::less::more/less}} inflammation than natural fiber sutures.
Synthetic nonabsorbable suture materials such as {{c1::nylon and Prolene::2}} have long been the gold standard for cuticular closure.
Prolene has the most {{c1::pliability}} and {{c1::knot-holding}} characteristic and is excellent for cuticular closure as well as vascular repair and approximation.
Nylon has a high level of {{c1::elasticity}} and retains the most {{c1::tensile strength}} of all synthetic materials.
Commonly used needles for wound closure include {{c1::tapered}} for deep sutures and {{c1::reverse cutting}} for skin closure.

Crikelair listed the Halstedian fundamentals of surgical
wound closure that apply to the management of any skin
wound. These principles are: 
(1) place incisions to follow {{c4::tension}} lines and {{c4::natural folds}} in the skin; 
(2) handle tissue gently and debride only as much as necessary to ensure an adequately clean bed; 
(3) ensure {{c3::complete hemostasis}}; 
(4) eliminate {{c2::tension}} at the skin edges; 
(5) use {{c5::fine}} sutures and
remove them early; and 
(6) allow time for {{c1::scars to mature}}
before repeat intervention.
Closing isolated soft tissue wounds as soon as possible has been shown to have improved postoperative {{c1::esthetic}} outcomes.
Ideally, closure of facial soft tissue injuries should occur within the first {{c1::8 hours}} after injury.
If wound contamination is present, wounds can be cleaned with a surgical antiseptic, preferably {{c1::chlorhexidine gluconate}}.
Irrigation volumes of {{c1::50 to 100 mL}} per cm of laceration length have been reported to be appropriate for contaminated wounds.
Pressure irrigation, which has been shown to improve decontamination of wounds, can be performed in the ED setting using a {{c1::35-cc}} syringe and an {{c1::18}} gauge catheter.

Clean, uncontaminated wounds treated early do not benefit
from irrigation according to one study.

Longmire21 found that pressures of 13 psi, generated
by using a needle and syringe, were effective in reducing
inflammation and infection when compared to irrigation
using a bulb syringe associated with lower pressures. Pressures
of 8-12 psi in the wound are believed to overcome the
adhesive forces of the introduced bacterium.

{{c1::Absorbable::absorbable/nonabsorbable}} suture, generally {{c1::3-0 and 4-0::size}}, are appropriate
for muscle layers, {{c2::4-0 or 5-0::size}} {{c2::Absorbable::absorbable/nonabsorbable}} sutures are appropriate
for dermal closure, and {{c2::5-0 to 7-0::size}} {{c3::nonabsorbable::absorbable/nonabsorbable}}
{{c3::monofilament::mono/braid}} sutures are used for skin layers.

{{c1::Cyanoacrylate}} tissue adhesive such as {{c1::Dermabond (Ethicon) or use of Steri-Strips (3-M)}} are appropriate in pediatric patients with uncomplicated, clean lacerations as they have been shown to be time saving, cost effective, and are less painful for the patient.

If palpable pulses are not appreciable and recipient vessels lie in the zone of injury, then {{c1::CTA (computed tomography angiography)}} is the definitive method to evaluate vessel patency and integrity.
{{c1::Head CT}} should be performed to rule out skull fractures prior to closure of scalp lacerations.
In scalp lacerations, closure of the {{c1::galea}} is important to achieve proper approximation of overlying soft tissue.

Lacerations of the forehead should be comprehensively evaluated with special attention to cranial nerves {{c1::V and VII}}. This is critical in the conscious patient and must be done prior to the use of any local anesthetic.
Closure materials include {{c1::5-0 and 6-0 plain gut}} for conjunctiva and orbicularis followed by {{c2::5-0 or 6-0 fast-absorbable plain gut}} or {{c2::6-0 nonabsorbable sutures}} for skin closure.

Lacerations of the lid margin and tarsal plate must be
approximated anatomically and the lid margin everted with
{{c1::vertical mattress}} sutures using {{c2::6-0 silk::size & type}} to prevent notching.
Medial lid lacerations require evaluation of the {{c1::lacrimal ducts and canaliculi}} and appropriate ophthalmologic consultation for repair.

Partial-thickness loss greater than {{c1::50}}% of either upper or lower lid requires full-thickness
skin graft.

Donor sites from the contralateral eyelid when
adequate skin exists or postauricular (as opposed to retro
auricular) full-thickness skin from the contralateral eyelid
when available provide satisfactory match in thickness
and color.
Cat bites are associated with a {{c1::twofold higher}} risk of infection than dog bites.

Cat bites are more likely to
cause a puncture injury with deep penetration, leaving
only a small opening through which fluids can drain.
In cat bites, as with dog bite wounds, {{c1::Augmentin}} is the prophylactic antibiotic of choice with good coverage of the most common pathogens.
Clindamycin should not be used alone due to poor coverage of Pasturella species.

The most common pathogens associated with human bites include Streptococcus and Staphylococcus species as well as anaerobic bacteria Eikenella, Fusobacterium, Peptostreptococcus, and Prevotella. The prophylactic antibiotic of choice is {{c1::Augmentin}}.
Clindamycin should not be employed due to poor coverage against Eikenella spp.
Complete {{c1::eyelid}} reconstruction can be achieved using microvascular transfer of dorsalis pedis with septal cartilage 28 or radial forearm flaps with palmaris longus tendon.29
{{c1::Medial canthus}} lacerations frequently involve the {{c2::canaliculi or lacrimal apparatus}} and should be addressed with ophthalmologic consultation and the Jones dye test.
Eyelid avulsion wounds require immediate {{c1::ophthalmic antibiotic ointment}} and an occlusive eye shield to prevent exposure {{c2::keratopathy. }}
{{c1::Berk, Osbourne, and Tay- lor}} found that wound age was of little concern in wounds located on the {{c2::scalp and face }}
Synthetic nonabsorbable suture materials such as {{c1::nylon}} and {{c2::Prolene}} have long been the gold standard for {{c3::cuticular/skin}} closure.
{{c2::Nylon}} has a high level of {{c1::elasticity}} and retains the most {{c1::tensile}} strength of all synthetic materials.
Prolene has the most pliability and knot-holding characteristic and is excellent for {{c1::cuticular}} closure as well as {{c2::{{c3::vascular repair}} and approximation. }}
Ideally, closure of facial soft tissue injuries should occur within the first {{c1::8}} hours after injury.
Soft tissue swelling associated with delay in wound closure can obscure anatomic landmarks and make primary closure more difficult.
Pediatric patients who do not tolerate injection of local anesthesia may require conscious sedation for proper management of soft tissue injuries larger than {{c1::3}} centimeters in length.
If wound contamination is present, wounds can be cleaned with a surgical antiseptic, preferably {{c1::chlorhexidine gluconate }}
Care must be taken not to scrub the wound because this can increase {{c1::inflammation}} and result in {{c1::poor esthetic outcome.}}
Irrigation volumes of {{c1::50 to 100 mL}} per cm of laceration length have been reported to be appropriate for contaminated wounds.

1. In high velocity or blast injuries, primary soft tissue closure is frequently not possible due to the need for multiple debridements. Clinically superior outcomes result from {{c1::early}} {{c2::soft tissue}} reconstruction, which prevents significant {{c3::contracture}} and provides better coverage for later osseous reconstruction.
1.  {{c1::Computed tomography angiography}} (CTA) is needed to evaluate recipient vessels for free flap reconstruction in patients with complex wounds.
1. {{c1::CTA}} is the definitive method to evaluate vessel patency and integrity.
Head {{c1::CT}} should be performed to rule out skull fractures prior to closure of {{c2::scalp}} lacerations
Scalp lacerations with defects smaller that {{c1::3}} cm can be closed primarily in most cases.
Avulsion wounds of the scalp that are a result of blunt or shear forces have {{c1::poor}} prognosis due to the vascular {{c2::intimal}} damage that propagates proximal and distal within the vessels,
Avulsion defects that are smaller can be managed with rotational flaps or advancement local flaps based off the {{c1::supraorbital}} or {{c1::supratrochlear}} vessels.
Closure materials include {{c1::5-0 and 6-0 plain gut}} for conjunctiva and orbicularis followed by {{c2::5-0 or 6-0 fast}}-absorbable plain gut or 6-0 nonabsorbable sutures for skin closure.
In lower lid lacerations anatomic approxima- tion and support are important to prevent {{c1::ectropion}}.
Ectropion a condition in which your eyelid turns outward.

Lacerations of the lid margin and tarsal plate must be approximated {{c1::anatomically}} and the lid margin {{c2::everted}} with {{c3::vertical mattress}} sutures using {{c4::6-0 silk}} to prevent {{c5::notching }}
In upper lid lacerations {{c1::levator aponeurosis}} integrity is important to establish to prevent {{c2::post-operative ptosis.  }}
When necessary, anatomic approximation of the aponeurosis with the tarsal plate can be performed with 6-0 or 7-0 polyglactin sutures placed central, medial, and lateral.27
Medial lid lacerations require evaluation of the {{c1::lacrimal ducts}} and {{c1::canaliculi}}
Partial-thickness loss greater than {{c1::50}} % of either upper or lower lid requires {{c2::full-thickness}} skin graft.
Lateral canthus can be recreated with suture repair of the {{c1::lower lid}} {{c2::tarsus}} to the {{c3::lateral orbit}} placed inside the rim.
Medial canthus lacerations frequently involve the {{c2::canaliculi}} or {{c4::lacrimal apparatus}} and should be addressed with ophthalmologic consultation and the {{c1::Jones dye test.}}
{{c1::Regeneration}} occurs when the healed tissue is structurally and functionally indistinguishable from the native tissue.
{{c1::Repair}} occurs when the tissue integrity is replaced primarily through formation of fibrotic scar tissue.

Repair by scarring is the body’s version of a spot weld and the replacement tissue is coarse and has a lower cellular content than
native tissue.
With the exception of {{c1::bone and liver::2}}, tissue disruption results in {{c1::repair}}.
(Rather than regeneration)
{{c1::Labile}} cells divide throughout their lifespan and include {{c2::keratinocytes}} of the epidermis and {{c2::epithelial cells}} of the oral mucosa.
{{c1::Stable}} cells exhibit a low rate of duplication but can undergo rapid proliferation in response to injury. These cells include {{c2::fibroblasts}} in the dermis.
{{c1::Permanent}} cell do not divide in the postnatal life. These include {{c2::specialized nerve}} in the CNS and {{c2::cardiac muscle cells}} in the heart.
The expectation of "normal healing" should be realistic and based on {{c1::the inherent capabilities}} of the injured tissue.
E.g. Labile, Stable, Permanent cells ability to replicate
At a macro level, the quality of healing is influenced by the {{c1:: nature of the tissue disruption}} and the {{c2::circumstances surrounding wound closure}}.
Healing by {{c1::first}} intention occurs when a clean laceration or surgical incision is closed {{c2::primarily}}.
Healing by {{c1::first}} intention proceeds {{c2::rapidly}} and assumes no dehisence and {{c2::minimal}} scar formation.
Healing by {{c1::second}} intention occurs when wound healing is more complicated and occurs through a protracted filling of the tissue defect with {{c2::granulation}} and {{c2::connective}} tissue.
Healing by {{c1::second}} intention is commonly associated with {{c2::avulsive}} injury, {{c2::local infection}}, or {{c2::inadequate}} closure of the wound.
Healing by {{c1::third}} intention occurs through a staged procedure that combines {{c2::secondary}} healing with {{c2::delayed primary closure}}.

Healing by {{c1::third}} intention involves {{c2::debriding the wound}}, allowing it to granulate and heal by second intention for {{c3::5-7}} days. Then, once risk for infection is minimal, to proceed to {{c2::suture close}} and allow healing by first intention.

children.name: Chapter 38: Principles of Mangement of Maxillofacial Infections

fields: Mortality of Ludwig's angina has been reduced to {{c1::4}}%.
According to Flynn and colleagues, there was trismus in {{c1::73}}% and dysphagia in {{c1::78}}% of patients at presentation.
The most common location for infection to enter the submandibular space is through the {{c1::lingual}} plate adjactent to the mandibular molars.
{{c1::Peptostreptococci}} bacteria were associated with cellulitis significantly more than with abscess.
{{c1::Hydration}} is perhaps the best method for controlling fever.
Fever increases metabolic demand by {{c1::5-8}}% per degree of fever per day.

The steps of managment of odontogenic infections are:
1. {{c1::Determine the severity of infection.}}
2. {{c2::Evaluate host defenses.}}
3. {{c3::Decide on the setting of care.}}
4. {{c4::Treat surgically.}}
5. {{c5::Support medically.}}
6. {{c6::Choose and prescribe antibiotic therapy.}}
7. {{c7::Administer the antibiotic properly.}}
8. {{c8::Evaluate the patient frequently.}}
The two main structures threatened by spreading odontogenic infections are {{c1::airway and mediastinum::2}}.

The buccal, infraorbital vestibular, and subperiosteal
spaces can be categorized as having {{c1::low}} severity.

The {{c1::masticator}} space's components may
be considered separately as the submasseteric, pterygomandibular, and superficial and deep temporal spaces, and the perimandibular spaces (submandibular, submental, and sublingual).
The lateral pharyngeal and retropharyngeal, the danger space, and the mediastinum are considered {{c1::high}} severity.
The stages of infection are {{c1::Inoculation, Cellulitis, Abscess, Resolution::4}}.
The book says 4 stages but only lists 3...
Swelling is soft, tender, and doughy during days {{c1::1-3}}.
Swelling is hard, red, and exquisitely tender during days {{c1::2-5}}.
The center of cellulitis begins to soften and becomes undermined by abscess during days {{c1::5-7}}.
The term {{c1::fluctuance}} implies the palpitation of a fluid wave b y one hand as the abscess is compressed by the other.
This is appropriately used once a true abscess has begun to form.
Rapidly progression infection, frequently caused by odontogenic sources, be manifest as {{c1::necrotizing fasciitis}}.
The anatomic course of infection of necrotizing fasciitis is from the {{c1::platysma}} to the {{c1::anterior chest wall}}.
Predisposing factors for necrotizing fasciitis include {{c1::diabetes and alcoholism::2}}.
Factors that increase mortality in necrotizing fasciitis include {{c1::medical compromise, delay in surgery, and mediastinitis::3}}.
The earliest signs of necrotizing fasciitis are {{c1::small vesicles}} and {{c2::dusky purple discoloration}}.
Repeated surgical debridement is to be expected for treatment of {{c1::necrotizing fasciitis}}.
The most frequent cause of death in odontogenic infection is {{c1::airway obstruction}}.
In complete airway obstruction {{c1::cricothyrotomy or tracheotomy}} is more predictably successful than endotrachial intubation.
The {{c1::sniffing}} postion includes the head inclined forward with an elevated chin.
Can be seen in patients with partial airway obstruction.
The {{c1::tripod}} position includes sitting with hands or elbows on the knees and the chest inclined forward with the head thrust anterior to the shoulders.
This position (along with sniffing position) straightens the airway and pulls the otngue forward to allow secretions to drool outward onto the floor or into a pan.
Patients with lateral pharyngeal space infection may incline the neck toward the {{c1::opposite}} shoulder.
This allows the positioning of the upper airways over the laterally deviated trachea.
MIP < 20 in a patient with acute pain should be considered an infection in the {{c1::masticator}} space until proved otherwise.
To get a good view, position the patient's occlusal plane {{c1::parallel}} to the plane of vision and shine a light coaxially to that plane.
When examining the patient for infections, you should look at the {{c1::position of the uvula}] and the {{c2::anterior tonsillar pillars}}.
The affected tonsillar pillar will usually be edematous and reddened, and will displace the uvula to the opposite side.
The {{c1::Mallampati}} test is correlated with difficulty of intubation along with {{c2::MIP < 20}}, and {{c3::decreased thyromental distance}}.
Only one independent study has really looked into this and showed that an abnormal malampatti test with a thyromental distance < 5cm is correlated with difficulty intubating.
An O2 sat below {{c1::94%}} in an otherwise healthy patient indicates insufficient oxygenation of tissues due to hypoperfusion or hypooxygenation.
The method of choice for evaluation of potential airway obstruction is {{c1::clinical examination plus contrast-enhanced CT}}.
This is also useful in characterizing the location and quality of infections in the head and neck.
The most common immune-compromising disease is {{c1::Diabetes}}.
Diabetes is an immune-compromising disease due to its effect on {{c1::WBCs (inhibits sucessful chemotaxis)}} and {{c2:: vascular beds (impairs blood flow in end organs)}}.
Almost every patient with malignant disease has some defect in their {{c1::immune}} system.

The mechanisms of immune compromise in malignancy are variable and not well identified, but the surgeon treating the patient with ongoing cancer should assume that there is some defect of the immune system.

All patients who have received cancer
chemotherapy within the past year should be considered
{{c1::immunocompromised}}.
HIV seropositivity {{c1::does not::does/does not}} increase the incidence of severe odontogenic infections.

Therefore, an elevated
temperature at {{c1::elderly}} age is a sign of a particularly
severe infection.

It is also an omen of decreased cardiovascular
and metabolic reserve owing to the demands
placed on the elderly patient’s physiology.

An otherwise mild or moderate
infection may be a significant threat to the patient with
systemic disease due to increased {{c1::physiologic stress}}.
E.g. diabetes, hypertension, renal disease, COPD, atherosclerotic heart disease all can become worse with infection.
Clinical signs of dehydration include {{c1::dry skin}}, {{c2::chapped lips}}, {{c3::loss of skin turgor}}, and {{c4::dry mucous membranes}}.
Normal serum creatinine in the presence of elevated urine specific gravity (>1.030) or elevated BUN indicates {{c1::dehydration}}.
Due to pre-renal azotemia.
Infection of moderate or high severity zones make {{c1::intubation}} difficult and indicate hospital admission.
Due to trismus, directly compressing or deviating the airway by swelling, or threatening vital structures directly.
{{c1::Immediate establishment of airway security}} and {{c2::early aggressive surgical therapy}} are the most important intervention steps in the management of severe odontogenic infections.
In patients that undergo anesthesia for dental infections due to inability to cooperate, it is recommended to maintain {{c1::endotracheal intubation}} postoperatively.

Because of the risks of continued spread of the infection and
additional swelling due to the trauma of surgery.

{{c1::Needle decompression}} is where, under local anesthesia, an abscess of the pterygomandibular, lateral pharyngeal, submandibular, or sublingual space is aspirated with a large bore needle in order to decompress the surrounding tissues.

"infrequently used surgical technique" but I'm not sure why.

This maneuver may decrease the risk of abscess rupture
through taut, distended oropharyngeal tissues during instrumentation of the airway.

Additional benefits of this procedure are the redirection of pus drainage into the oral cavity or onto the skin, where it can easily be removed, and obtaining an excellent specimen for culture and sensitivity testing.

An intraoral vertical incision over the {{c1::pterygomandibular raphe}} can be used to drain the pterygomandibular and submasseteric spaces as well as the anterior compartment of the lateral pharyngeal space.
To reduce chances of {{c1::crushing}} a vital structure, hemostats should never be blindly closede while inside a surgical wound.
Wound irrigation is facilitated especially by the use of a {{c1::Jackson-Pratt–type}} drain, which is noncollapsible and perforated.
A large, Barton dressing may be used because it {{c1::avoids tape on the skin}}, and {{c2::can occlude and absorb drainage}}.
But, it has not been shown to substantially alter the outcome of cases of odontogenic infection.
Pus usually stops flowing from surgically drained abscesses in {{c1::24-72 hours}}.
May take longer when only cellulitis has been encountered.
Latex penrose drains may cause {{c1::exudation}} owin to foreign body reaction alone.
They can be antigenic.

Failure of the medical approach is determined by {{c1::patient  deterioration}}, {{c2::impending airway compromise}}, and the identification of {{c3::an abscess}} by CT or clinical examination or both.

Only then is surgical drainage undertaken!

This is the "Expectant approach" of managment.
Another strategy to manage infections is immediate establishment of {{c1::airway}} security and aggressive {{c1::early}} surfical intervention.

Identification of an abscess is not required
before surgical intervention. The approach by Williams and
Guralnick2 is predicated on the concept that early incision
and drainage aborts the spread of infection into deeper and
more critical anatomic spaces, even when it is in the cellulitis
stage.

In a prospective case series of 37 patients hospitalized
with severe odontogenic infections, Flynn and colleagues performed surgical drainage on all patients as soon as possible after admission. In none of their cases did incision and drainage seem to hasten the spread of infection. The need for reoperation and length of hospital stay were not significantly different between those patients in whom abscess and those
in whom cellulitis was found.

Routine culture and sensitivity testing for minor oral
infections {{c1::does not::does/does not}} appear to be justified.

In the absence of immunologic or systemic compromise, such infections are very unlikely to become serious or life-threatening. Straightforward treatments, such as removal of the involved teeth, intraoral incision and drainage, and empirical antibiotic therapy, are almost always successful. In this setting, it can be hard to justify the increased cost of routine culture and antibiotic sensitivity testing. Furthermore, because most odontogenic pathogens are slow-growing species, identification can become an expensive and time-consuming task for the microbiology laboratory. This expense is hard to justify, given the fact that, at least until recently, the oral flora is routinely sensitive to penicillin. Therefore, most microbiology laboratories, when given a specimen that grows out α-hemolytic streptococci mixed with short, anaerobic, weakly gram-negative rods will report the growth of normal oral flora, thus avoiding the necessity for species identification and subsequent antibiotic sensitivity testing.

Culture and sensitivity testing is also justified when the
surgeon is dealing with infections that {{c1::have had multiple prior courses of antibiotic therapy}} or in {{c2::chronic infections that are recalcitrant to therapy}} or in moderate or highly severe spaces.

Immunocompromised patients also tend to harbor unusual pathogens, such as {{c1::Klebsiella pneumoniae}} in diabetics, {{c2::methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus}} in intravenous drug abusers, and {{c3::intracellular pathogens, such as mycobacteria}} in HIV/AIDS.

Culture and sensitivity testing should be performed
in {{c1::unusual infections}}, the {{c2::medically and immunocompromised}}, and certainly in all cases severe enough to require {{c3::hospitalization}}.

The culture transport system should be designed to maintain
the viability of {{c1::anaerobic}} organisms, which do not survive in commonly available culturette systems.
Fluid aspirates and swab cultures of infected sites yield {{c1::valid::valid/invalid}} cultures.
Mild temperature elevations promote {{c1::phagocytosis}},{{c2:: blood flow}} to the affected area, {{c3::metabolic rate}}, and {{c4::antibody function}}.

Above {{c1::103°}}F, fever can become destructive by increasing metabolic and cardiovascular demands beyond physiologic reserve capacity. Energy stores can be rapidly depleted and the loss of fluid is significantly increased.

Daily {{c1::sensible}} fluid loss, consisting primarily
of sweat, is increased by {{c2::250}}mL per degree of fever.
{{c1::Insensible}} fluid loss, consisting mainly of evaporation from lungs and skin, is increased by {{c2::50 to 75}}mL per degree of fever per day.

A 70-kg patient with a fever of 102.2°F would have a daily fluid requirement of about {{c1::3100 mL}}. This would translate to a required intravenous infusion rate of approximately {{c1::130 mL/hr}}, assuming no oral intake and no other extraordinary fluid losses.

Fever increases metabolic demand by {{c1::5% to 8%}} per
degree of fever per day.
{{c1::Amoxicillin}} is the oral antibiotic of choice for uncomplicated odontogenic infections.
Of the macrolides, {{c1::azithromycin}} is the most advantageous for odontogenic infections.
Not metabolized by CYP, fewer drug rxns.

In vitro antibiotic sensitivity testing hasrecently shown that the macrolide antibiotics are <font color="#ff0000">generally ineffective against oral anaerobes</font> and even streptococci, the fact that azithromycin is concentrated in phagocytic macrophages by 10 to 15 times the serum concentration may explain its clinical effectiveness for oral infections when combined with appropriate surgical therapy.
In severe infections, Flynn found a {{c1::21}}% failure rate of penicillin G when used empirically.
Should not be used in hospitalized patients.
Clindamycin resistanfce rates among oral strep are up to {{c1::17}}% of cases.

Uptodate paper says to use it in conjuction with <font color="#ff0000">levofloxacin or meropenem</font>. Or if non-severe allergy and known to be able to use cephalosporins, to use<font color="#ff0000"> Ceftriaxone and metronidazole</font>.

{{c1::Ampicillin-sulbactam (Unasyn)}} is now the antibiotic
of choice in odontogenic infections that are serious enough
to warrant hospital admission.
{{c1::Streptococcus anginosus, S. constellatus, and S. intermedius::3}} are the viridans streptococci that comprise the Streptococcus {{c2::milleri}} group.

The {{c1::S. milleri}} group of pathogens is most commonly found in odontogenic abscesses, and fortunately, it remains sensitive to the natural and semisynthetic penicillins, such as penicillin V and amoxicillin.
The {{c1::penicillins and metronidazole::2 antibiotics}} have the advantage of crossing the bloodbrain barrier when the meninges are inflamed.
Clindamycin {{c1::does not::does/does not}} cross the blood-brain barrier.

It is appropriate to use {{c1::penicillin plus metronidazole}} or
{{c2::ampicillin-sulbactam}} when there is a risk of an odontogenic infection entering the cranial cavity.
Bc they can cross the BBB.

{{c1::Ceftriaxone}} can cause pseudocholelithiasis
owing to sludging of bile salts, it should be used with
caution or avoided in patients with {{c2::hepatobiliary disease}}.
{{c1::Ceftriaxone}} is effective against the oral streptococci and most oral anaerobes. Among the cephalosporins, therefore, {{c1::ceftriaxone}} is an alternative antibiotic of choice.

{{c1::Fluoroquinolones}} are the antibiotics of
choice for {{c2::E. corrodens}}, which is always resistant to Clindamycin.

They penetrate bone well.

E.g. Moxifloxacin. CAN be given orally (that's a good thing) bc PICC line can't always be used.
Metronidazole is active only against {{c1:: obligate anaerobic}} bacteria.

The use
of metronidazole alone may be an appropriate stratagem
when all of the other appropriate antibiotics are contraindicated.
With the fluoroquinolones and the aminoglycosides, if the serum concentration achieved is {{c1::three to four}} times the MIC for the organisms involved, then maximum killing power will be achieved.
These are concentration dependent antibiotics.

{{c1::Time-}}dependent antibiotics, such as the {{c2::β-lactams and vancomycin}}, antibiotic effectiveness is determined by the duration for which the serum concentration of the antibiotic remains above the MIC.

With time-dependent antibiotics,
it is necessary to know the serum elimination halflife
(t1/2) of the antibiotic in order to determine its proper
dosage interval. The dosage interval can then be designed in
order to maintain the serum concentration above the MIC for
at least 40% of the dosage interval.29
When it comes to time-dependent antibiotics, IV administration is {{c1::more::equal, more, less}} effective than oral administration.

For example, when penicillin G is given every 4 hours intravenously, a peak serum blood level of 20 μg/mL  is achieved. Because the serum elimination t1/2 of penicillin G is 0.5 hours, after 3 hours (6 halflives) the serum concentration will be approximately 0.3 μg/ mL. Because the MIC90 of Streptococcus viridans is 0.2 μg/ mL, the serum concentration of penicillin G after an intravenous dose of 2 million units will remain above the MIC90 for approximately 75% of the dosage interval. Therefore, penicillin G, 2 million units given intravenously every 4 hours, should be highly effective against the viridans group of streptococci, especially the abscess-forming S. milleri group. By the same method, the peak serum level that can be achieved with an oral dose of 500 mg of amoxicillin is 7.5 μg/mL, and its t1/2 is only 1.2 hours. Because amoxicillin’s MIC90 for viridans streptococci is 2 μg/mL, the serum concentration of amoxicillin will fall below the MIC90 at approximately 2 hours after the peak serum level has been achieved, which is only 25% of the 8-hour dosage interval. Therefore, oral amoxicillin, even though it is considered
by many to be a more effective antibiotic, is less likely to be effective against the viridans streptococci than intravenous penicillin G.
One study found that in odontogenic infections, surgery is {{c1::primary::primary/adjunctive}} and antibiotics are {{c1::adjunctive::primary/adjunctive}}.

In a randomized clinical trial of outpatient odontogenic
infections comparing amoxicillin, cephalexin, and surgery
alone (all patients received extraction and/or incision and
drainage), there was no statistically significant difference in
cure rate between the groups. The time to resolution was
nearly significantly shorter in the antibiotic-assisted groups.
This study indicates that surgical treatment is primary, and
antibiotic therapy as adjunctive.36
It {{c1::is::is/is not}} appropriate to take the cost of the antibiotic into account when deciding what drug to use.

By {{c1::2 to 3}} postoperative days, the clinical signs of improvement should be apparent, such as decreasing swelling, defervescence, cessation of wound drainage, declining white blood cell count, decreased malaise, and a decrease in airway swelling such that extubation can be considered.

If the previous signs of clinical improvement are not
apparent, then it may be necessary to begin an investigation
for possible treatment failure.

Also at this time, preliminary Gram stains and/or
culture reports should be available, which may provide some
guidance as to the appropriateness of the empirical antibiotic
therapy

Causes of Treatment Failuring following Odontogenic Infection: SAND Bod For DADS
{{c1::Inadequate Surgery}}
{{c4::Antibiotic problems}}
{{c5::Patient Noncompliance}}
{{c2::Depressed host Defenses}}
{{c3::Foreign body}}
{{c7::Drug Dosage too low}}
{{c8::Wrong bacterial Diagnosis}}
{{c9::Wrong Antibiotic}}
{{c6::Drug not reaching Site}}
The best available clinical test for the ability to extubate in the case of upper airway swelling is {{c1::the air leak test}}.

The air leak test is performed in the following manner in the
spontaneously ventilating patient:
1. The endotracheal tube and trachea are suctioned.
2. The oxygen supply is reconnected and any coughing that
was stimulated by the tracheal suctioning is allowed to
subside.
3. The oropharynx and oral cavity are suctioned free of
debris, hemorrhage, and secretions.
4. The cuff of the endotracheal tube is deflated while the
oxygen supply is maintained.
5. After waiting for any coughing to subside, the oxygen
supply is disconnected and the surgeon’s thumb is placed
to occlude the opening of the endotracheal tube.
6. The patient is then instructed to breathe spontaneously
around the endotracheal tube, and if this can be done, a
positive air leak test is obtained. If the patient cannot
breathe around the occluded endotracheal tube, then a
negative result is obtained and extubation should be
delayed.
A {{c1::postive}} air leak test result means that the patient {{c2::can::can/cannot}} breathe around the endotrachial tube during the test.
Extubation can proceed.

The surgeon’s mnemonic for the causes of a fistula can
is “FETID”, which stands for {{c1::foreign body}}, {{c2::epithelium}}, {{c3::tumor}}, {{c4::infection}}, and {{c5::distal obstruction}}.
Provides a DDx for the chronic drainage of pus.

Foreign bodies may be represented
by bone plates and screws or dental or cosmetic
facial implants. Epithelium may cause chronic drainage simply
because an epithelialized fistulous tract has not been
completely excised or because an epithelium-lined cyst has
drained externally. Tumors (especially malignant ones) that
become infected do not heal, which may result in chronic
drainage. Infection can, of course, drain chronically, which
should alert the surgeon to suspect osteomyelitis or a chronic
periapical abscess that is draining onto the skin, as in Figure
38-14. Distal obstruction classically refers to intestinal
obstructions, but the concept can still be applied to the salivary
ducts and to the natural sinus drainage pathways, such
as the ostium of the maxillary sinus. When these openings
for natural drainage of saliva or mucus become obstructed,
infection may result and drainage may occur by an alternate
pathway, such as proximal fistulization of the submandibular
salivary duct due to a salivary stone blocking the natural
opening of Wharton’s duct.

Criteria for Changing Antibiotics:
{{c1::Allergy, toxic reaction, or intolerance}}
{{c2::Culture and/or sensitivity test indicating resistance}}
{{c3::Failure of clinical improvement, given}}
{{c4::Removal of odontogenic cause}}
{{c5::Adequate surgical drainage (suggest postoperative imaging)}}
{{c6::Other causes for treatment failure ruled out}}
{{c7::48–72 hr of the same antibiotic therapy}}

The clinical diagnosis of acute sinusitis includes pain
overlying the involved sinus(es), which may range from a
dull ache to throbbing pain, usually constant but exacerbated
by {{c1::bending over or straining}}.

Early on, the only presenting symptom in sinus infection may be {{c1::pain in the posterior maxillary dentition}} on the
affected side.
E.g. Ipsilateral molars tender to percussion.
Discharge in acute nasal sinusitis is usually {{c1::profuse, clear}}.
Discharge in chronic nasal fistula is usually {{c1::congestive, purulent}}.

{{c1::Aspiration of pus}} from the involved sinus is the
gold standard of diagnosis of sinus infection.
Signs of {{c1::sinusitis}} include tenderness to finger pressure, unilateral postnasal discharge, edema of the middle and inferior nasal turbinates, polyp formation, and opacity on transillumination.
Sinusitis is considered acute and bacterial between {{c1::10 days and 4 weeks}} after onset of symptoms.
Sinusitis is considered chronic after at least {{c1::8 weeks}} of symptoms.
{{c2::Subacute}} sinusitis is diagnosed between {{c1::4 and 8 weeks::time}}.
Recurrent sinusitis is {{c1::four}} or more episodes within 1 year.
The common pathogens of bacterial head and neck infections are the {{c1::Streptococci::group}} and the anaerobes, such as {{c1::Peptostreptococcus, Fusobacterium, Prevotella, and Porphyromonas::4}}.
In acute sinusitis, {{c2::viruses::bacteria/viruses}} cause {{c1::the vast majority::minority/majority}} of infections.
Acute bacterial sinusitis cultures generally yield {{c1::Staphylococcus, Moraxella, Haemophilus, and Streptococcus::4}}; chronic bacterial sinusitis yields predominantly the anaerobic species.

Culture and sensitivity testing of sinus can be done via:
1. {{c1::Intranasal aspiration}}
2. {{c2::
Large-bore needle aspiration of the maxillary
sinus intraorally}}
Antibiotic therapy {{c1::is not::is/is not}} indicated in the first 7 days of acute sinusitis.

..unless signs of invasive infection and severe
systemic reaction are present, because nearly all early sinusitis is viral.

If indicated to use antibiotics, treatment until
{{c1::7 days}} after symptoms have resolved helps to prevent relapse.
Treatment of bacterial sinusitis include first-line, inexpensive antibiotics such as {{c1::amoxicillin, doxycycline, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole::3}}.
Second-line antibiotics include {{c1::amoxicillin-clavulanate, clindamycin, a macrolide plus metronidazole, or fluoroquinolones such as moxifloxacin}} and are continued for {{c2::3 to 10 weeks}}.

Second-line antibiotics are indicated for complicated sinusitis, such as when bacterial resistance is likely, as with prior antibiotic therapy; in moderate to severe sinusitis, as in recurrent or prolonged sinusitis or pansinusitis; with comorbidities such as diabetes or immunocompromise; and at the extremes of age (<2 or > 55 yr).
Most cases of uncomplicated chronic sinusitis are probably due to {{c1::the inflammatory response to allergens or fungi}} instead of bacterial pathogens.

Thus, the largely anaerobic
flora of chronic sinusitis may be commensal rather than
pathogenic. Intranasal or systemic steroids are usually more
effective than antibiotic therapy for chronic sinusitis without an identifiable cause amenable to surgery, such as oroantral
fistula or retained foreign body.

Rarely, recurrent or persistent sinusitis leads to  intracranial infection, such as brain abscess, subdural empyema, or cavernous sinus thrombosis, generally by direct extension through thin layers of bone or via {{c1::emissary veins}} passing from the involved sinus into the intracranial structures.
The treatment of intracranial extension of sinusitis is {{c1::surgical débridement, if possible, and prolonged aggressive antibiotic therapy}}.
Incision over the anterior belly of digastric leads to {{c1::Submandibular,Submental,Sublingual::3}} spaces

Indications of Hospital Admission includes:
{{c1::Dehydration}}
{{c2::Threat to airway or vital structures}}
{{c3::Need for general anesthesia}}
{{c4::Need for inpatient control of systemic disease}}
{{c5::Temperature over 101F}}
Adequate {{c1::Hydration}} is best method for controlling fever
Specific gravity greater than {{c1::>1.030}} indicates {{c2::dehydration }}
{{c2::E. Corrodens}} is COMPLETELY resistant to {{c1::Clindamycin}}
{{c1::Diabetes}} have a combination of white blood cell {{c2::migration defect}} and {{c3::a vascular defect}} that {{c4::impair blood flow}}
Every patient of malignant disease has some {{c1::defect}} of the {{c2::immune system }}
All patient who received cancer chemotherapy with the past {{c2::one}} year should be considered {{c1::immunocompromised}}
{{c1::Dehydration}} can be assessed in the presence of normal serum creatinine by an {{c2::elevated}} {{c3::specific gravity}} {{c4::(>1.030)}} or elevated BUN which indicates pre-renal azotemia
pathway for odontogenic infection to enter the submandibular space is through the {{c2::thin }} {{c3::lingual}} plate of the mandible {{c1::(root apices of lower molar teeth)}}
wound irrigation is facilitated by using {{c1::Jackson-Pratt-type drain}} which is {{c2::noncollapsible}} and {{c2::perforated }}
{{c2::Initial temperature}} has been shown to be a significant predictor of the {{c1::length}} of hospital stay with severe odontogenic infections
Fever below 103F is probably {{c1::beneficial }}
{{c3::Mild}} temperature elevations promote {{c2::phagocytosis,}} {{c1::increase}} blood flow to the affected area and raise the metabolic rate
Antibiotics is not indicated in the first {{c1::7}} days of acute sinusitis unless signs of {{c1::invasive}} infection and severe {{c1::systemic }} reaction are present
This is because nearly all early sinusitis is viral
Treatment of bacterial sinusitis include first in line {{c1::amoxicillin}}, {{c1::doxycycline}} and {{c1::TMP-SMX}} (Cotrimoxozole)
In the case of infectious invasion of the surrounding tissues, {{c1::antibiotics}} should be continued {{c1::7}} days after symptoms have resolved.
Sinusitis is conisdered bacterial and acute between {{c2::10}} days to {{c1::4}} weeks
Sinusitis is considered {{c2::chronic}} after {{c1::8}} weeks of symptoms
{{c1::recurrent}} sinusitis is {{c2::4}} or more episodes within {{c3::one}} year
{{c1::CT}} is the radiologic examination of choice in {{c2::confirming}} diagnosis of sinusitis
majority of {{c2::acute}} sinusitis is caused by {{c1::virus }}
Most common causes of acute Bacterial sinusitis {{c2::S. Pneumo}},  {{c2::Haemophilus influenzae}}, {{c1::Moraxella catarrhalis}}

Chow AW, Benninger MS, Brook I, Brozek JL, Goldstein EJ, Hicks LA, 
Pankey GA, Seleznick M, Volturo G, Wald ER, File TM., Infectious 
Diseases Society of America.  IDSA clinical practice guideline for acute
 bacterial rhinosinusitis in children and adults. Clin. Infect. Dis. 2012 Apr;54(8):e72-e112.
A rare cause of acute rhinosinusitis is {{c1::fungal}} infection
Most exclusively in immunocompromised individuals ; Mucor, Rhizopus, Rhizomucor, and Aspergillus.
Radiologic signs of sinusitis include thickening of the mucosal sinus lining >{{c1::4}}mm
{{c2::Sinusitis}} is usually constant dull ache to throbbing pain usually exacerbated by {{c1::bending over}} or {{c1::straining }}
In the event of treatment failure one of the best methods of re-evaluation is post op {{c1::CT }}
The best available clinical test for ability to extubate in the case of upper airway selling is the {{c1::air leak test }}
There is {{c1::little}} evidence to indicate that {{c1::frequent}} wound irrigation {{c2::hastens}} the resolution of infection
However it does make clinical sense to remove by irrigation pus clots and necrotic tissue

{{c5::When to go the OR include}}
{{c4::Moderate to high anatomic severity }}
{{c3::Multiple Space involvement }}
{{c2::Rapidly progressing infection }}
{{c1::Need for general anesthesia }}
{{c6::To establish airway security}}

children.name: Chapter 17: Management of Alveolar and Dental Fractures

fields: In the pediatric group, the primary cause of alveolar and dental injuries is {{c1::falls}}.

In the larger surveys, the
pediatric population accounts for {{c1::5}}% of all facial fractures.
Approximately one third of all dental trauma is secondary to {{c1::sporting accidents}}.

One study found that most orofacial
injuries resulted from {{c1::intentional violence}}, and the
victims were primarily socially and economically disadvantaged
groups in the minority populations.

One study found that a significantly greater proportion of
patients who screened positive for drug and alcohol abuse at
the time of injury had {{c1::a previous history of head injury and/
or orofacial injury}}.

Other groups at increased risk of dentoaveolar trauma are
those with {{c1::seizure}} disorders, {{c1::mental}} disorders, and {{c1::congenital
maxillofacial abnormalities}}.

Poor {{c1::laryngoscopy}} technique and the
unmonitored {{c1::biting force}} of the comatose patient also potentially
caused dentoalveolar injury.

Lockhart and associates14 reported findings, by the Risk
Management Foundation, indicated that damage to the teeth
was the most frequent anesthesia-related claim, often resulting
in litigation.

With direct trauma, {{c1::maxillary incisors}} are the most frequently
traumatized teeth, especially if they are associated
with a {{c1::class II division 1}} malocclusion.

Trauma to the primary
dentition usually results in various {{c1::luxations}} (~75%),
whereas in permanent dentition, {{c2::crown, or crown-root fractures}}
are the norm (39%).

Indirect trauma to the dentition
usually results from the forceful impact of the mandible
with the maxilla, following a blow to the chin region. These
traumas will often result in injury to the {{c1::posterior}} teeth.

Davidoff and colleagues20 reported
that it was not uncommon for a closed head injury to result
when a loss of consciousness of less than {{c1::1 hour}} occurred,
along with facial trauma.

In the case of unaccounted-for avulsed teeth, {{c1::auscultation of the chest to rule out wheezing or
labored breathing::test}} is essential.

Owing to its anatomic position,
the right mainstem bronchus is often the site of foreign
body dislodgment. Support any positive finding with proper
neck, chest, and abdominal radiographs.
If foreign bodies exist in the abdomen, arrange follow-up for the patient with
radiographs, and monitor for the risk of gastrointestinal
obstruction until the foreign body is cleared.

Consider {{c1::tetanus}}
prophylaxis, depending on previous immunization compliance
and wound presentation.

Success rates are timedependent
with dentoalveolar trauma, and generally perioral
soft tissue lacerations (lips) should be repaired {{c1::after::before/after}} intraoral
treatment, except in cases of poor hemorrhage control.

Buccal mucosal lacerations should raise the suspicion
for {{c1::Stensen’s duct or orifice}} injuries.

Account for all fractured or missing teeth and
restorations or assume they were {{c1::swallowed, aspirated, or
lodged within adjacent structures}}.

Similarly, arrange for
radiographic evaluation of the maxillary and nasal sinuses
before further treatment.28

{{c1::Sublingual ecchymosis}} at the
floor of the mouth is pathognomonic for an underlying mandible
fracture.

Step defects, crepitation, malocclusion, and
gingival lacerations all raise suspicion of possible underlying
{{c1::bony defects/fractures}}.

{{c1::Gentle percussion}} of the injured and noninjured
control teeth is the technique of choice to rule out PDL injury.
Also test pulp vitality of teeth in question.

Acutely injured teeth may revascularize in approximately
1 month, thus increasing the risk of {{c1::false-negative}}
results during pulp testing.

Radiographic examination is essential to determine whether
any underlying structures are damaged and should include
{{c1::periapical, occlusal, and panoramic::3}} radiographs.

When occlusal radiographs or periapical films are
used to examine soft tissues for the presence of foreign bodies,
you should {{c1::reduce the radiographic exposure time}}.

In the trauma patient whose tooth has not been accounted
for at the accident scene, arrange for {{c1::chest films}} to rule out
the possibility of aspiration.
Ellis class {{c1::III}} involves the crowns pulp, dentin, and enamel.

With pulp exposure, the
preferred treatment is {{c1::calcium hydroxide}} placed directly over
the exposure and sealed in place with a {{c1::glass ionomer}} cement
followed by a dentin-bonding agent and composite.

The prognosis is best for teeth with a vital pulp exposure
if the fracture is treated within the first {{c1::2 hours}}.

Treatment of mobile root fractures consists of apposition of
the fractured segments with rigid splinting for {{c1::12 weeks}}.

children.name: Chapter 18: Contemporary Management of Mandibular Fractures

fields:
When a force is applied to the parasymphysis
region of the mandible, a compressive strain develops
along the {{c1::buccal}} aspect, and tensile strain occurs along the
{{c1::lingual}} surface.

A fracture will occur on the lingual side of
the mandible, which then propagates to the buccal side (Figure
18-5). The contralateral condyle is pushed into the glenoid
fossa and fractured by compressive forces.

The presence or absence of posterior teeth was, for many
years, thought to contribute further to fracture patterns.57–59 It
turns out, however, that this may be true only for the {{c1::impacted
third molar}}.

Some evidence suggests that there is no correlation
between posterior occlusion and the incidence or pattern
of mandibular fracture, except when impacted third molars
were present, when the incidence fractures of the {{c1::angle}} were
significantly more common.

Dr. {{c1::Thomas Gilmer}} of Chicago was, in 1881, the first modern
surgeon to advocate what we now consider IMF for the
treatment of complex maxillomandibular fractures.

"Special Cases" of mandibular fracture that required more than just {{c1::closed IMF}} included:
1. a fracture in the molar or premolar region with a long edentulous posterior fragment;
2. fractures in the molar or premolar region with teeth in the posterior fragment but no opposing teeth in the upper jaw;
3. fractures of the edentulous or almost edentulous mandible;
4. fractures of the mandible with an edentulous upper jaw; 
5. comminuted fractures at the symphysis with loss of incisor teeth and bone; 
6. fractures of the mandible complicated by fractures
of the maxilla
This is the OLDER way of thinking.
This type of device is named a {{c1::Joe Hall Morris}} external fixator for the mandible.

There appears
to be no significant advantage of {{c1::compression}} plating in the
mandible, and in fact, it may contribute to the development
of diastasis if not utilized properly.
Many OMS surgeons have abanoned the use of compression plating in favor of {{c1::miniplate fixation}} and/or the use of {{c1::locking plates and screws}}.
These lines represent {{c1::champys lines of ideal osteosynthesis}}.
I believe this is the region of tension where he recommended putting a miniplate.

If utilized, bridle wires should be placed through {{c1::the second tooth on either side of the fracture}} to prevent avulsion of a mobile tooth or teeth fragments. The patient is placed on a full liquid diet and scheduled for treatment expeditiously.
The administration of {{c1::antibiotics}} should begin as soon as possible for all mandibular fractures that extend through the tooth-bearing regions.

Many surgeons also prescribe {{c1::chlorhexidine gluconate}}
oral rinse before and after surgery until all wounds/
incisions are closed.

{{c1::Pre}}operative antibiotics have been
shown to significantly reduce the incidence of {{c1::post}}operative
infections.

There is conflicting evidence for the use of
postoperative antibiotics. Neither of the two most recent prospective,
randomized, clinical trials could prove a benefit to
the postoperative administration of antibiotics in patients
who underwent ORIF of mandibular fractures.110,111
In general, {{c1::Erich arch bars, interdental “Stout wires,” and manual reduction alone::3}} all have efficacy for achieving favorable bony union in the ORIF of selected mandibular fractures.

{{c1::Erich}} arch bars are preferable for
the treatment of comminuted fractures and those mandibular
fractures with concomitant midfacial fractures.

{{c1::Comminuted fractures of the ramus of the mandible,
gunshot wounds and atrophic mandibular fractures::3}} are
relatively common indications for the use of transcervical
or transfacial incisions

{{c1::Rigid}} stability occurs when no
movement whatsoever occurs across the fracture gap.
Ideal, but not realistic.

{{c1::Functional}} stability occurs when movement is possible across the
fracture gap but is balanced by external forces and remains
within the limits that allow for the fracture to progress to
union.

Excessive mobility at a fracture site will lead to {{c1::bone
resorption and fibrous tissue ingrowth}}.

Load-{{c1::bearing}} fixation is provided by locking reconstruction
plates, generally {{c2::2.3, 2.4, and 2.7}} mm in diameter.
Load-{{c1::sharing}} fixation is generally {{c2::2.0}} mm in diameter.

Champy lines are based upon the concept
that only {{c1::tensile}} stresses are harmful to fracture healing

Fractures located proximal to the first premolar may
be safely stabilized with a single miniplate placed in the
{{c1::midbody position (2.0 mm)}}.

Fractures anterior to the first
premolar should be stabilized with {{c1::two (a tension
band and a compression band)}} plates.
Separated by 4 to 5 mm and generally placed on either side of the mental nerve.

The preponderance of
evidence suggests that teeth in the line of fracture (including
third molars) may be retained providing that they {{c1::do not
interfere with favorable reduction, stabilization, and fixation
of the fracture}} and are not {{c2::grossly mobile or infected}}.
{{c1::Medial}} pressure is applied to {{c2::the angles}} of the mandible in cases of comminution or when the mandibular condyles are also involved, to prevent {{c3::facial widening}}.

Careful attention should be paid to cases of bilateral mandibular fractures involving the {{c1::symphysis or parasymphysis}}.
Lateral muscular forces will cause {{c2::widening}} of the mandible by {{c2::splaying the angles outward}} and creating a defect on the {{c3::lingual}} aspect of the anteriormost fracture.

Care must be taken to avoid screw placement
into the roots of teeth; but if this does occur, it may be
of {{c1::little}} consequence.

In addition, there is clinical and experimental
evidence to suggest that permanent damage to the
pulp and supporting tissues is a rare occurrence when screws
abrade or even enter root substance.134–138 The need for postoperative
endodontic therapy is extremely rare.
Fractures of the {{c2::mandibular angle}}, have been shown to have the {{c1::highes}}t rate of postoperative complications of all mandibular fractures
These fractures are often complicated by the presence of a third molar.

Regarding mandibular angle fractures, a study found that a single, noncompression miniplate placed in Champy style via a transoral approach
yielded a complication rate of {{c1::only 2.5}}%.
{{c1::Sixteen}} percent of patients with mandibular angle fractures experienced complications requiring a second surgical intervention.

However, most of the complications
were minor and could be treated in the office.

For the majority of noncomminuted isolated
fractures of the mandibular angle, a single 2.0-mm miniplate is placed at the {{c2::superior}} border. A second 2.0-mm miniplate
may be added to {{c1::either the inferior border or just below the
first}} using a transbuccal trocar for additional stability.
